comprehensive.question: Trace the establishment and succession of Awadh from Saadat Khan's rise (1722) through Safdar Jung to the Battle of Buxar (1764).
comprehensive.answer: Founder: Saadat Khan (Burhan-ul-Mulk) established Awadh autonomy in 1722. Rise: He rose from Faujdar of Biyana - a relatively modest Mughal position - demonstrating how provincial officials could establish autonomous states during Mughal decline. 1722 establishment made Awadh one of the early Successor States. Succession: Safdar Jung succeeded Saadat Khan in 1739, maintaining Awadh's autonomous status. This represented 17 years of Saadat Khan's rule establishing the foundation. Decline: Safdar Jung faced defeat at Battle of Buxar (1764), marking Awadh's decline. This battle was a turning point where British East India Company defeated combined forces, establishing British dominance in the region. Timeline: 1722 (autonomy) → 1739 (succession) → 1764 (decline) spans 42 years of Awadh as an autonomous Successor State. Pattern: Awadh followed classic Successor State trajectory - provincial official establishing autonomy, succession maintaining state, eventual defeat by British/European powers marking transition to colonial control.

comprehensive.question: Compare Awadh's establishment (Saadat Khan from Faujdar) with Hyderabad's establishment (Nizam-ul-Mulk from Wazir) as Successor States.
comprehensive.answer: Similarities: Both Successor States founded by former Mughal officials establishing autonomy in early 18th century (Awadh 1722, Hyderabad 1724). Both demonstrated pattern of provincial autonomy during Mughal decline. Different Starting Positions: Saadat Khan rose from Faujdar of Biyana - a relatively modest provincial military/administrative position. Nizam-ul-Mulk was former Mughal Wazir - the highest administrative position in the empire. Military Establishment: Both used military victory to establish control - Saadat Khan established autonomy in 1722, Nizam won Battle of Shaker-Kheda (1724). Succession: Awadh: Safdar Jung (1739), then decline at Buxar (1764). Hyderabad: succession crisis (1748), stability under Nizam Ali Khan (1762). Durability: Hyderabad became one of wealthiest states lasting into British Raj and Indian independence. Awadh's decline marked by Battle of Buxar (1764) came earlier. Awadh vs Hyderabad shows that even from different starting positions (Faujdar vs Wazir), Mughal officials could establish Successor States, but long-term survival varied based on succession management and military outcomes against emerging powers (British for Awadh, better balance for Hyderabad).
